body: For the last five years, Cobble Hill has prospered with New York City, its stately brownstones drawing young couples to its quiet streets just blocks from downtown Brooklyn. title: Cobble Hill Denounces Plan for a Homeless Shelter

body: Perhaps someone spiked the punch or hung too much mistletoe years ago, because across the city, schools were bursting at the seams in 1998. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: THE YEAR IN SCHOOL DAYS; Classroom Crowding Is the Mother of Innovation

body: IN parts of Brooklyn these days, even the dullest community board meeting can count on coverage by half a dozen local newspapers. The opening of a supermarket might draw a phalanx of photographers. These papers have their bigger stories, too. ''Rats! Super Vermin Are Taking Over the Streets'' shouted a recent cover of The Brooklyn Graphic. The
title: NEW YORKERS & CO.; In Brooklyn, There's No Stopping the Presses

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: COBBLE HILL; What's In A Name? A Contest

body: Just before 6 P.M. in the 23d Street subway station, an F train was on the track, waiting, and R. Anthony Williams was perched on a station bench, watching. The train was heading to Queens. So was Mr. Williams. Five, six, eight minutes, and the train did not move. Neither did he. ''I'm just getting off of work, I got new shoes, my feet hurt,'' said
title: A Subway Rider's Dream: Some Room to Breathe; Passengers List Ways to Spend a Surplus

body: Homicide detectives were questioning a Brooklyn woman and her boyfriend yesterday in the death of the woman's 20-month-old daughter, whose body was found in Gravesend Bay shortly after she was reported kidnapped, the police said. The woman, whose name was withheld by the police, reported her child's disappearance to officers around 8:30 A.M.
title: Mother Is Questioned in Death Of Toddler Reported Kidnapped

body: SUR, an Argentine restaurant in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, opened about five weeks ago on a previously barren stretch of Smith Street that in the last year has seen the arrival of several boutiques and restaurants like Patois and Rosina's. At dinner one recent night, my friends and I were wondering why neighborhood restaurants like Sur and Patois
title: $25 AND UNDER; An Argentine Rendezvous for the Meat-Eating Crowd

body: IN New York, many regular people -- meaning those who do not make hundreds of thousands of dollars a year -- do not think of landlords as being like them. title: Habitats / Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn; An Apartment Seeker Becomes a Landlord

body: AS befits the co-author of a 1,383-page history of New York City -- and that's only Volume I -- Mike Wallace is not a man of few words. Just give him a topic: J.P. Morgan! The Erie Canal! title: PUBLIC LIVES; What Can He Say About New York? Plenty

title: PUBLIC LIVES; A Collector of New York Pictures, in Words

title: In Combining Apartments, 1 + 1 = 2+

title: EATING OUT; Bistros

title: PERSPECTIVES; A Middle-Income Housing Program Gathers Steam

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CARROLL GARDENS; 'Moonstruck' Bakery Eclipsed

body: PERHAPS no other profession touches so many New Yorkers' lives but is as unregulated as that of building superintendent. Many trades have exams and licenses, but the only hint in New York City law that supers even exist is a requirement that buildings with 16 or more units have a janitor on or within 200 feet of the premises 24 hours a day. The law
title: MAKING IT WORK; Supers Trade Tips and Tales of Woe

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CARROLL GARDENS; Blackout. Murder. Mystery.

The suspect is described as a black man about 25 years old, 5 feet 8 inches tall and weighing about 200
title: Police in Brooklyn Seek Serial Rapist In Subway Assaults

body: The news that a woman had been raped this weekend aboard a G train operated without a conductor shocked women riding the line yesterday -- but the assault was not the only source of their dismay. ''I thought every train had a conductor on it,'' said a passenger, Carol Johnson, as she waited yesterday for the G train at the Smith-Ninth Streets
title: Subway Rape Raises Concern About Reduced Train Crews

body: A 21-year-old woman was raped and robbed on a G train in Brooklyn late Saturday night, the police said yesterday. There was no conductor on the train because New York City Transit has been running weekend G trains without conductors since March, despite the objections of critics who warned that the trains would be more dangerous. The woman and her
title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK; Woman Raped on Train That Had No Conductor

body: Construction will start this month on 74 town house-style co-ops on Staten Island that are part of a new city program to provide housing that is affordable to people who earn as little as $30,000 a year. title: Residential Real Estate; Staten Island Co-op Project Is Priced for Moderate Incomes

body: THE thick, green water of the Gowanus Canal was baking in the hot August sun. Hollow windows of empty buildings and twisted fences brooded down on the water. title: The Gowanus Canal: An Appreciation

body: EVERY night, behind millions of closed eyelids, little New York movies flicker, as fleetingly as yesterday's fireworks: images of an Upper West Side apartment where one room opens into another, then another; of verdant midtown oases; of downtown lofts with streets running through them, of an A train that takes the dreamer far from Harlem. The
title: Streets of Dreams; When You're Asleep, New York Becomes Another World

body: Roberta Fineberg hoped that the summons she got for riding her bike on the sidewalk along Court Street would serve as a legal test case in which she would emerge the winner. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CARROLL GARDENS -- UPDATE; Small Victory for a Bicyclist

title: Gunman Fatally Shoots Man in a Brooklyn Park

body: To the Editor: The article states that David Nuss of the No-Neck Blues Band tackled Mike O'Neal but that's not the way I saw it. title: Refugees, Musicians and Ferries; Band's Skirmish Raises Question on Public Space

title: 3 Convicted in Racial Beating in Brooklyn

body: Todd Neuhaus, an advertising executive, and his wife, Christina, didn't want much. They wanted to rent a Manhattan apartment for less than $3,000 with a bedroom for themselves and one for their two boys. They wanted it to be near good public schools, because private school was beyond their means. Most of all, the Neuhauses wanted to believe it
title: For Middle Class, New York Shrinks as Home Prices Soar

body: DONALD PIERRE could not find the home he wanted for the price he could pay in his old neighborhood, Crown Heights, Brooklyn -- the one that would work for his growing family and bring in a bit of rental income. title: Manhattan Strength Lifts All Boroughs

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GREENPOINT; Without Conductors, G Trains Stand for 'Ghost,' Critics Say

title: A Brooklyn Man Is Missing, And a Family's Search Begins

body: For more than 35 years, as Cobble Hill, Park Slope, and other Brooklyn neighborhoods of brownstone and old brick have revived, a mile-long corridor through the middle of the area has continued to crumble, collect weeds and drive people away. title: Flushing Out the Foul And the Frustration; A New Vista for a Dead-End Canal

title: Man Killed Was Mobster, Police Say
